column1: The Lenape and ancestral indigenous peoples were the original inhabitants of Mahwah (the meeting place) and surrounding area. Their descendants have combined with other Native Americans and ethnicities and were recognized in 1980 by the state as the Ramapough Mountain Indians. They number approximately 5
column2: 000 people living around the Ramapo Mountains of northern New Jersey and southern New York. The tribe is officially recognized by New Jersey
column3: but does not have federal recognition. Their tribal office is located on Stag Hill Road in Mahwah
column4: and the Chief of the Ramapough Lenape Indian Nation is Dwaine Perry (as of March 2007).In 1849
column5: Hohokus Township was established from the northern part of Franklin Township in Bergen County. It extended from the Saddle River on the east to the western boundary of Bergen County with Passaic County and north to the New York border. Hohokus Township was first subdivided in 1886 with the creation of Orvil Township on both sides of the Saddle River
column6: consisting of the eastern portion of Hohokus Township and the western portion of Washington Township. 1894's outbreak of "Boroughitis" brought the creation of the boroughs of Allendale and Upper Saddle River
column7: both of which were created from portions of Hohokus and Orvil Townships. Next to leave was Ramsey

column1: Mahwah is governed within the Faulkner Act (formally known as the Optional Municipal Charter Law) under the Mayor-Council system of municipal government (Plan B)
column2: implemented by direct petition as of July 1
column3: 1984. The township is one of 71 municipalities (of the 565) statewide that use this form of government. The governing body is comprised of the Mayor and the seven-member Township Council
column4: with all members elected at-large to staggered four-year terms of office on a non-partisan basis as part of the November general election in even-numbered years. Four council seats are up for vote together and then three seats and the mayoral seat are up for vote together two years later. The legislative powers of the township are exercised by the Township Council. In September 2010
column5: the township council voted to shift the township's non-partisan elections from May to November
column6: citing increased voter participation and prospective savings of $30
column8: with the first November election taking place in 2012.As of 2020
column9: the Mayor of Mahwah is John Roth
column10: who was elected to replace William Laforet and serve the balance of the term of office ending December 31
column11: 2020. Mayor Roth was elected in November 2018 following a recall of the former mayor. Members of the Township Council are Council President David May (2020; elected to serve an unexpired term)
column12: Council Vice President George W. Ervin (2022)
column15: Michelle Crowe Paz (2020; elected to serve an unexpired term)
column16: Jonathan Wong (2022) and James Wysocki (2020).Then-Mayor Bill Laforet faced a recall election in November 2018
column17: after a resident group submitted in June a list of 5
column18: 000 petition signatures that they had collected calling for the action
column19: in excess of the 25% needed to place the measure in front of voters. In the November 2018 general election
column20: Laforet was recalled from office and John Roth was elected mayor. The successful recall was the first in the county for at least 25 years.Michelle Crowe Paz was appointed to fill the seat expiring in December 2020 that was vacated following the resignation of Steven Sbarra that became effective at the end of December 2017
column21: and was elected in her own right in November 2018 to fill the unexpired term.At the January 2017 reorganization meeting
column22: David May was sworn in to fill the seat expiring in December 2020 that had been won by Jonathan Marcus in the November 2016 general election
column23: but which Marcus decided not to accept; May was elected in his own right in the November 2017 general election
column24: to serve the balance of the term.In December 2016
column25: the Township Council selected George Ervin to fill the seat that had been held by Mary Amoroso expiring in December 2018 that became vacant after she was elected the Bergen County Board of Chosen Freeholders; Ervin served on an interim basis until the November 2017 general election
column26: when voters elected him in his own right to fill the balance of the term. Ervin was re-elected in the November 2018 election to fill a full four-year term
